title: Unknown Title
body:
Byline: Mingtao Huang
Sihua Wei
Jiansen Xia
Body
ABSTRACT
Background
Moral courage is a recognized virtue. Researchers have focused on various aspects of nursing moral courage, such as its conceptualization and influencing factors. Within these studies, various literature reviews have been conducted, but to our knowledge, bibliometric mapping has not been utilized.
Aim
This article aims to analyze the production of literature within nursing moral courage research.
Research Design
To investigate publication patterns, we employed VOSviewer and CiteSpace software, focusing on publication dynamics, prolific research entities, and most cited articles. Additionally, we forecasted future research trends.
Ethical considerations
In our study, ethical review was not required.
Results
A total of 105 information sources were identified in the WoS database. Overall, there has been a significant increase in research volume after 2020. The most prolific countries are the United States, Finland, and China, while the most prolific source title is “Nursing Ethics.” Keywords are also related to moral dilemmas and ethics. However, there are further improvements needed in international cooperation.
Conclusions
The results proposed in this paper can serve as a starting point for comprehensive or systematic literature reviews and seek more detailed data, information, and knowledge in the field of nursing moral courage. It can enable outsiders to quickly understand research on nursing moral courage, whether for in-depth exploration or simply to facilitate more effective collaboration with nursing ethics experts.
FULL TEXT
Introduction
Moral courage is defined as the ability to rationally defend ethical principles and act accordingly despite possible adverse consequences.1 Moral courage is one of the key characteristics of the nursing profession and is a significant tool for dealing with ethical issues.2 Studies have shown that during the COVID-19 pandemic, nurses needed strong moral courage to work on the front lines.3 Faced with ethical quandaries, nurses must navigate the delicate balance between fulfilling their professional obligations and exercising sound judgment in the swift ethical decisions demanded by practical circumstances. This underscores the indispensable role of moral courage in nursing practice.4
Over the past two decades, there has been a notable surge in the volume of scholarly literature addressing nursing moral courage. Various researchers have employed diverse methodological approaches to investigate the conceptual underpinnings, influencing determinants, and contextual exigencies pertinent to moral courage among nurses.2,5,6 Furthermore, certain studies have delved into the nuanced manifestations of moral courage within distinct cohorts, such as disaster relief nurses and candidates pursuing nursing master’s degrees.7,8 Through these inquiries, it has been elucidated that moral courage serves as a crucial nexus, reconciling individual ethical convictions with professional imperatives.9 Moreover, moral courage not only equips nurses to navigate moral quandaries autonomously but also facilitates an elevated standard of patient care, contributing to enhancements in patient safety, as well as the overall quality of care and patient well-being.5
Despite the existence of several review articles, the current corpus of literature falls short in providing a comprehensive overview of the evolving research landscape concerning nursing moral courage. As such, to enhance understanding of existing scholarship, qualitative analyses in the form of integrative, systematic, and scoping reviews should be complemented by quantitative methodologies. A prominent quantitative approach is bibliometrics, which encompasses various counting techniques and a sophisticated method known as bibliometric mapping.10 To our knowledge, the utilization of bibliometrics in scrutinizing literature production within the domain of nursing moral courage remains scarce. In this study, we employed VOSviewer and CiteSpace, two data analysis software tools, for our investigation. VOSviewer, developed by Van Eck and Waltman,11 is a software tool used for constructing and visualizing bibliometric networks. These networks can include relationships among publications, authors, keywords, and citations. The software features a powerful function that creates bibliometric maps, which clearly visualize the structure and connections within the scientific literature. CiteSpace was developed by Chen12 to implement 2 complementary visualizations: cluster view and time zone view.
Bibliometric mapping utilizes text mining and co-word analysis methodologies to elucidate relationships among pairs of words or phrases extracted from research literature. Diverging from conventional reviews that typically yield tabular presentations of evidence, bibliometric mapping offers a visual representation of the thematic content embedded within research publications, akin to scientific landscapes.13
Aim
The aim of this study is to conduct a quantitative analysis of literature output in the domain of nursing moral courage utilizing the bibliometric methodology. Specifically, our focus lies in scrutinizing patterns in literature production, identifying the leading countries and source titles, and discerning the frequently cited information sources. To this end, the following research inquiries were formulated:1. What trajectory characterizes the literature output on nursing moral courage?2. How is the distribution of literature production on nursing moral courage dispersed among the most prolific source titles, institutions, and countries?3. What trajectory is anticipated for future research endeavors in the realm of nursing moral courage, and how might these evolve over time?
Materials and methods
Data collection
The search was conducted on 20 February 2024. The Web of Science (WoS) Core Collection served as the data source in this study. We retrieved articles containing both the keywords “moral courage” AND “nursing” as well as those with the keyword “moral courage” and related keywords such as “moral resilience,” “moral dilemma,” and “moral sensitivity.” The beginning time point for data collection was 2000-01-01 to 2023-12-31, and the study period for the retrieved articles was from 2002 to 2023.
Analysis methodologies
The bibliometric approach was first introduced by Alan Pritchard.14 Bibliometrics is a method of information analysis that measures research trends and knowledge structures in a field to obtain quantifiable, objective data.15 Bibliometric analysis employs quantitative methodologies to scrutinize patterns in research literature production, encompassing facets such as identifying preeminent authors, institutions, countries, and journals within a disciplinary domain, delineating citation patterns, assessing temporal trends in literary output, and elucidating dynamics of authorial communication and collaboration.16 Despite the potential insights that can be gleaned about nursing and its sub-specialties through the analysis of published information sources and their citation records, bibliometric studies remain underutilized in the field of nursing.10
We opted for VOSviewer and CiteSpace as our analytical tools due to their respective strengths. VOSviewer offers superior visualization capabilities for network and cluster analyses, while CiteSpace excels in literature timeline analyses. By combining these two tools, we aimed to effectively fulfill our research objectives. Employing VOSviewer (version 1.6.20), we generated diagrams for institutional collaboration, journal co-citation, keyword co-occurrence, author collaboration, author co-citation, and literature co-citation. Furthermore, we utilized CiteSpace (version 6.3.1) to produce two analytical mappings: keywords bursting and Keyword Timeline Graph.
Results
The search of the WOS database resulted in 105 information sources (among them, 94 original articles, 8 reviews, 2 editorial materials, and 1 meeting abstract) published between 2002 and 2023. The authors decided to include all types of information sources because all of them represent literature production in the field of nursing moral courage (Table 1).Table 1.PRISMA flow diagram for Web of Science data collection.
Overall trends in publications and citations
Figure 1 illustrates the publication trends in the domain of nursing moral courage. From the initial publication in 2002 through 2023, there was a consistent and discernible upward trajectory in the number of articles, indicative of an overarching growth trend. Regarding the average annual publication rate, the trend delineates two distinct stages: (1) from 2002 to 2019, characterized as a gestation period, during which the number of publications remained in the single digits; and (2) since 2020, witnessing a rapid proliferation in nursing moral courage research.Figure 1.Total publications from 2002 to 2023.
Country distribution
About 89.5% (94/105) of the publications were from the top 10 productive countries or regions shown in Table 2. The United States ranked first with 28 published articles, accounting for 26.7% of all 105 publications and far exceeding the numbers of other countries. Finland was second (12/105, 11.4%), followed by China (11/105, 10.5%).Table 2.Top 10 publication countries/regions (N = 105).
Journal distribution
Table 3 displays the top 10 journals based on publication count, along with their respective total citation frequencies. As anticipated, Nursing Ethics ranked first with 31 publications, constituting 29.5% of the total 105 articles, and boasted the highest citation frequency at 565 citations. This outcome aligns with expectations, given the longstanding emphasis within nursing ethics on nurturing and fostering moral courage among nurses. Notably, Nursing Ethics serves as a repository of exemplars and narratives illustrating nurses’ adherence to ethical principles and demonstration of moral courage. Consequently, it not only offers insights into the experiences of nurses but also serves as a source of inspiration and reference for readers.Table 3.Top 10 most productive journals. (N = 105).
Table 3 reveals a discrepancy between the ranking of journals based on the number of articles published and their corresponding citation counts. Certain journals exhibit relatively high citation counts despite their comparatively modest publication output, suggestive of the potential variance in the quality of publications across these journals.
Co-occurrence of keywords
Keywords can serve as indirect indicators of trends and shifts in research topics, facilitating a comprehensive understanding of their evolution. Employing VOSviewer, we constructed a keyword co-occurrence network (depicted in Figure 2). Furthermore, Table 4 presents the top 10 keywords based on their occurrence frequency. Notably, “moral courage” emerged as the most frequently occurring keyword, appearing 44 times, with a total link strength of 77. Additionally, keywords such as “nurses,” “ethics,” “moral distress,” and “nursing” are prominently featured, ranking highly in both occurrence frequency and connection strength.Figure 2.Keyword co-occurrence network.Table 4.Top 14 most frequently occurring keywords of nursing moral courage.
Keyword timeline graph
Keyword co-occurrence analysis unveils the evolution of research topics within a designated field over a specified time period. Through the generation of a timeline clustering graph predicated on clustered keywords, it delineates the historical progression and temporal duration of distinct keyword developments within each cluster. Utilizing the timeline view module within CiteSpace software, we produced a timeline map illustrating the research keywords pertaining to nursing moral courage, as depicted in Figure 3.Figure 3.Keyword timeline graph.
Keywords with the strongest citation bursts
Keywords exhibiting the most pronounced citation bursts can delineate periodic fluctuations in the prevalence of specific terms, thus facilitating prognostication of developmental trends and emerging research frontiers within the field. Leveraging the burst detection functionality of CiteSpace software, a statistical graph depicting keyword bursts within the domain of nursing moral courage was generated. In this graph, red indicates keywords experiencing bursts in a given year, while blue signifies non-burst keywords. Additionally, “Begin” and “End” denote the commencement and conclusion of each burst period, respectively, while “Strength” quantifies the intensity of the keyword burst, with higher values denoting greater influence (Figure 4).Figure 4.Keywords with the strongest citation bursts.
Author distribution
Table 5 presents the top 10 most productive authors. A total of 10 articles were published by Leino-Kilpi, who ranks first in terms of citations.Table 5.Top 10 most productive authors.
We also analyzed co-authorships using VOSviewer. In Figure 5, color represents cluster, node size represents publications, and link thickness represents collaboration strength.Figure 5.Co-authorship network based on publications.
The number of articles published by an author does not reflect the quality or popularity of their work. We thus further analyzed the co-authorship network based on citations (Figure 6).Figure 6.Co-authorship network of authors based on citations.
To better reflect the impact and contributions of the authors’ research, we conducted a co-citation analysis of the cited references in 105 articles (Figure 7).Figure 7.Co-citation network.
Articles with high citation numbers
Based on the keyword co-occurrence and author co-operation analysis, we further explored the cited articles. Table 6 reports the top 10 articles according to number of citations.Table 6.Top 10 articles according to number of citations.
Discussion
The primary objective of this research was to examine the scholarly output in the domain of moral courage in nursing through a mixed-method approach incorporating bibliometric analysis, mapping techniques, and thematic analysis. This methodology was employed to contextualize our research within a wider interdisciplinary framework that integrates insights from nursing ethics, psychology, and social science, thus providing a comprehensive perspective on the subject matter. In our research, we employed bibliometric analysis using VOSviewer and CiteSpace, which are robust tools for visualizing and analyzing patterns in scientific literature. The strengths of these tools lie in their ability to provide quantitative, objective data that help identify trends, key authors, institutions, and thematic shifts within the domain of nursing moral courage. VOSviewer, in particular, is renowned for its superior visualization capabilities, enabling detailed network and cluster analyses that are crucial for understanding the interconnections within the data. CiteSpace offers excellent support for literature timeline analyses, helping to highlight the evolution of research topics over time.
Our literature bibliometric analysis identified two distinct phases in the field. The initial phase, spanning from 2002 to 2019, was characterized by limited research activity, typically yielding single-digit annual publications. However, a significant surge in research was noted from 2020 onwards, coinciding with the global outbreak of COVID-19. This period has been marked by a robust increase in publication volume, suggesting a watershed moment in the field.
In numerous nations, nurses find themselves operating amidst the challenges posed by the ongoing pandemic, contending with insufficient resources and personal protective equipment, a surge in patient numbers, staffing deficits, inadequately prepared healthcare systems, and disruptions in the supply chain. This situation exacts a toll on the physical and emotional well-being of nurses and other healthcare and emergency personnel, inducing moral distress stemming from conflicts between professional values. They confront daunting and intricate ethical dilemmas in their daily practice, characterized by moral quandaries, heightened patient acuity, increased mortality rates, and prolonged work shifts. The exigencies of frontline pandemic response demand nurses to exhibit robust moral courage.3 The challenges created by COVID-19 can shape the students’ professional identity, making nursing students think about how to become excellent nurses.25 Nevertheless, it is undeniable that factors brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic will seriously affect their moral courage.26 Therefore, it may be under the influence of COVID-19 that research on nursing moral courage has shown explosive growth, highlighting the importance of moral courage in nursing.
While the COVID-19 pandemic undeniably played a pivotal role in this surge—necessitating robust moral courage among nurses who faced unprecedented challenges such as resource shortages, patient surges, and heightened ethical dilemmas—it is important to acknowledge that moral courage in nursing has also been influenced by other factors. Prior to the pandemic, topics such as authentic leadership,27 moral distress,28 and moral sensitivity20 were already prominent themes in moral courage research. These areas have contributed to a rich foundation of knowledge that has been critical in framing the current understanding of moral courage in the face of a pandemic. These factors have been fundamental in preparing nurses to handle the complex ethical situations that have become more frequent during the pandemic. Additionally, our analysis of the top 10 ranked keywords over the years highlights how concepts like “ethical decision-making,” “resilience,” and “professional integrity” have remained central to discussions on moral courage, alongside the recent focus on COVID-19. In summary, while the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted and intensified the need for moral courage in nursing, it is one of several critical factors that have shaped research in this field. Recognizing the broader spectrum of influences enriches our understanding and ensures a comprehensive exploration of moral courage in nursing.
According to research findings, the top 10 countries and regions in terms of published papers are mostly Western countries, except for China and Iran. However, this does not directly imply a lack of moral courage among nurses in Eastern countries and regions. In Confucianism, a prominent philosophical tradition in China, moral courage is construed as a form of courage associated with righteousness, ethics, and rational understanding, as evidenced by mentions in the writings of Confucius and Mencius. However, they did not specifically address what moral courage entails for nurses. This parallels the stance of Western philosophical scholars, as the term “moral courage” did not emerge in English until the 19th century, distinguishing it from other forms of courage such as physical courage.29 Presently, Western scholars have conducted research on the concept of moral courage in nursing, a topic relatively scarce in Eastern countries. Current research has not juxtaposed the conceptual and substantive disparities concerning nursing moral courage between Eastern and Western countries. Hence, this remains an area necessitating further investigation in the future.
It is also important to consider the relative contribution of each country in the context of their overall research output. For instance, while the United States produced the highest number of articles, its extensive research infrastructure and larger population naturally contribute to higher publication numbers across various topics, including nursing moral courage. Conversely, Finland, despite being smaller and having fewer research institutions, shows a remarkably high relational share in this specific area, underscoring its significant impact and specialization in nursing moral courage research. This highlights the importance of evaluating the relative impact of smaller countries, which can have a substantial influence despite producing fewer publications overall.
From the perspective of the most prolific journals, “Nursing Ethics” remains in the lead, having published a total of 31 scholarly articles, constituting 29.5% of the entire corpus. Additionally, half of the most frequently cited top 10 references are from “Nursing Ethics.” This journal, dedicated to nursing ethics, concentrates the dissemination of research findings on nursing moral courage; hence, its prominent position in this field is unsurprising. Furthermore, other journals such as BMC Nursing have also featured content related to moral courage, indicating that researchers seek opportunities not only to publish articles on moral courage in journals specifically focused on nursing ethics but also to integrate such content into more broadly accessible journals, such as those in psychology or education.
From the analysis of the top 10 most frequently occurring keywords related to nursing moral courage, it is evident that besides moral courage itself, there is a prevalence of keywords associated with moral dilemmas, ethics, and virtues. Nursing, as a moral practice, necessitates the courage to uphold ethical standards, take a firm stance on what is right, and live according to one’s moral values.2 Moral courage is not only a highly esteemed element in human morality but also a recognized virtue in contemporary nursing.30 Nurses encounter moral dilemmas in their daily practice, which should be resolved in the best interest of the patients, aligning with the moral aims of nursing.31 Thus, moral courage is introduced as an empowering mechanism for addressing these issues.
From the collaborative outcomes of the authors, it is disappointing. Since the era of Florence Nightingale in nursing literature, there has been a longstanding discourse on moral courage,2 which should be a fundamental characteristic of excellent nurses. However, to date, it has not received the same level of attention as discussions on moral dilemmas32 nor has it formed a realm of extensive scholarly collaboration. Perhaps this also represents a future research trend, namely, strengthening collaboration across multiple global regions.
Through comprehensive analysis combining keyword clustering, keyword timelines, authors, and countries, future research trends in nursing moral courage may manifest in several aspects. Firstly, there is a global perspective. Given the interplay of global nursing practices, researchers may adopt a global perspective to compare the manifestations of nursing moral courage and its influencing factors across different countries and regions, thereby fostering a global dialogue on nursing ethics. Secondly, interdisciplinary research is likely to emerge. Considering that moral courage encompasses multiple fields such as ethics, psychology, and sociology, future studies may employ interdisciplinary research methods and collaborate with philosophers, psychologists, sociologists, and others to gain a more comprehensive understanding of nursing moral courage. Lastly, education may become a focal point. As nursing education evolves, integrating content on moral courage into nursing curricula and cultivating moral courage in nursing students will become important research directions. This may include incorporating elements such as moral decision-making and discussions on ethical dilemmas into the curriculum. Naturally, as these studies progress, the definition and connotations of nursing moral courage will deepen, and research tools will become more diversified.
Limitations
This study has three main limitations. Firstly, in terms of data selection, the WoS Core Collection was chosen, while other databases such as Scopus were not included. Secondly, this research primarily focuses on journals, paying less attention to other modes of scientific knowledge dissemination (such as books, working papers, and reports). Lastly, we only analyzed English publications, potentially introducing language bias. Additionally, bibliometric analysis, while powerful for mapping out the landscape of a research domain, may not capture the full depth of individual studies’ contributions or the nuances of qualitative research. It relies heavily on the availability and accuracy of citation data, which can be influenced by factors such as publication bias and the varying impact factors of journals. This method also does not address the quality of the content itself, focusing instead on quantitative metrics. Future research could compare articles published in different languages or countries.
Conclusion
From a methodological perspective, it can be asserted that the innovative application of bibliometric analysis and mapping constitutes valuable tools for the analysis of literature production in the field of nursing moral courage. This study utilizes VOSviewer and CiteSpace visualization analysis tools to systematically review and summarize research on nursing moral courage. We roughly delineate it into two phases, and bibliometric analysis suggests that there is still room for further exploration of nursing moral courage in terms of content and geography. However, this does not diminish its significance in addressing ethical dilemmas encountered in nursing practice. It is noteworthy that this paper also forecasts future research trends in nursing moral courage, indicating that researchers may strengthen research on nursing moral courage by adopting a global perspective, engaging in interdisciplinary studies, and focusing on nursing education. The results proposed in this paper can serve as a starting point for comprehensive or systematic literature reviews and seek more detailed data, information, and knowledge in the field of nursing moral courage. It can enable outsiders to quickly understand research on nursing moral courage, whether for in-depth exploration or simply to facilitate more effective collaboration with nursing ethics experts.

ABSTRACT
Background
Moral courage is a recognized virtue. Researchers have focused on various aspects of nursing moral courage, such as its conceptualization and influencing factors. Within these studies, various literature reviews have been conducted, but to our knowledge, bibliometric mapping has not been utilized.
Aim
This article aims to analyze the production of literature within nursing moral courage research.
Research Design
To investigate publication patterns, we employed VOSviewer and CiteSpace software, focusing on publication dynamics, prolific research entities, and most cited articles. Additionally, we forecasted future research trends.
Ethical considerations
In our study, ethical review was not required.
Results
A total of 105 information sources were identified in the WoS database. Overall, there has been a significant increase in research volume after 2020. The most prolific countries are the United States, Finland, and China, while the most prolific source title is “Nursing Ethics.” Keywords are also related to moral dilemmas and ethics. However, there are further improvements needed in international cooperation.
Conclusions
The results proposed in this paper can serve as a starting point for comprehensive or systematic literature reviews and seek more detailed data, information, and knowledge in the field of nursing moral courage. It can enable outsiders to quickly understand research on nursing moral courage, whether for in-depth exploration or simply to facilitate more effective collaboration with nursing ethics experts.
FULL TEXT
Introduction
Moral courage is defined as the ability to rationally defend ethical principles and act accordingly despite possible adverse consequences.1 Moral courage is one of the key characteristics of the nursing profession and is a significant tool for dealing with ethical issues.2 Studies have shown that during the COVID-19 pandemic, nurses needed strong moral courage to work on the front lines.3 Faced with ethical quandaries, nurses must navigate the delicate balance between fulfilling their professional obligations and exercising sound judgment in the swift ethical decisions demanded by practical circumstances. This underscores the indispensable role of moral courage in nursing practice.4
Over the past two decades, there has been a notable surge in the volume of scholarly literature addressing nursing moral courage. Various researchers have employed diverse methodological approaches to investigate the conceptual underpinnings, influencing determinants, and contextual exigencies pertinent to moral courage among nurses.2,5,6 Furthermore, certain studies have delved into the nuanced manifestations of moral courage within distinct cohorts, such as disaster relief nurses and candidates pursuing nursing master’s degrees.7,8 Through these inquiries, it has been elucidated that moral courage serves as a crucial nexus, reconciling individual ethical convictions with professional imperatives.9 Moreover, moral courage not only equips nurses to navigate moral quandaries autonomously but also facilitates an elevated standard of patient care, contributing to enhancements in patient safety, as well as the overall quality of care and patient well-being.5
Despite the existence of several review articles, the current corpus of literature falls short in providing a comprehensive overview of the evolving research landscape concerning nursing moral courage. As such, to enhance understanding of existing scholarship, qualitative analyses in the form of integrative, systematic, and scoping reviews should be complemented by quantitative methodologies. A prominent quantitative approach is bibliometrics, which encompasses various counting techniques and a sophisticated method known as bibliometric mapping.10 To our knowledge, the utilization of bibliometrics in scrutinizing literature production within the domain of nursing moral courage remains scarce. In this study, we employed VOSviewer and CiteSpace, two data analysis software tools, for our investigation. VOSviewer, developed by Van Eck and Waltman,11 is a software tool used for constructing and visualizing bibliometric networks. These networks can include relationships among publications, authors, keywords, and citations. The software features a powerful function that creates bibliometric maps, which clearly visualize the structure and connections within the scientific literature. CiteSpace was developed by Chen12 to implement 2 complementary visualizations: cluster view and time zone view.
Bibliometric mapping utilizes text mining and co-word analysis methodologies to elucidate relationships among pairs of words or phrases extracted from research literature. Diverging from conventional reviews that typically yield tabular presentations of evidence, bibliometric mapping offers a visual representation of the thematic content embedded within research publications, akin to scientific landscapes.13
Aim
The aim of this study is to conduct a quantitative analysis of literature output in the domain of nursing moral courage utilizing the bibliometric methodology. Specifically, our focus lies in scrutinizing patterns in literature production, identifying the leading countries and source titles, and discerning the frequently cited information sources. To this end, the following research inquiries were formulated:1. What trajectory characterizes the literature output on nursing moral courage?2. How is the distribution of literature production on nursing moral courage dispersed among the most prolific source titles, institutions, and countries?3. What trajectory is anticipated for future research endeavors in the realm of nursing moral courage, and how might these evolve over time?
Materials and methods
Data collection
The search was conducted on 20 February 2024. The Web of Science (WoS) Core Collection served as the data source in this study. We retrieved articles containing both the keywords “moral courage” AND “nursing” as well as those with the keyword “moral courage” and related keywords such as “moral resilience,” “moral dilemma,” and “moral sensitivity.” The beginning time point for data collection was 2000-01-01 to 2023-12-31, and the study period for the retrieved articles was from 2002 to 2023.
Analysis methodologies
The bibliometric approach was first introduced by Alan Pritchard.14 Bibliometrics is a method of information analysis that measures research trends and knowledge structures in a field to obtain quantifiable, objective data.15 Bibliometric analysis employs quantitative methodologies to scrutinize patterns in research literature production, encompassing facets such as identifying preeminent authors, institutions, countries, and journals within a disciplinary domain, delineating citation patterns, assessing temporal trends in literary output, and elucidating dynamics of authorial communication and collaboration.16 Despite the potential insights that can be gleaned about nursing and its sub-specialties through the analysis of published information sources and their citation records, bibliometric studies remain underutilized in the field of nursing.10
We opted for VOSviewer and CiteSpace as our analytical tools due to their respective strengths. VOSviewer offers superior visualization capabilities for network and cluster analyses, while CiteSpace excels in literature timeline analyses. By combining these two tools, we aimed to effectively fulfill our research objectives. Employing VOSviewer (version 1.6.20), we generated diagrams for institutional collaboration, journal co-citation, keyword co-occurrence, author collaboration, author co-citation, and literature co-citation. Furthermore, we utilized CiteSpace (version 6.3.1) to produce two analytical mappings: keywords bursting and Keyword Timeline Graph.
Results
The search of the WOS database resulted in 105 information sources (among them, 94 original articles, 8 reviews, 2 editorial materials, and 1 meeting abstract) published between 2002 and 2023. The authors decided to include all types of information sources because all of them represent literature production in the field of nursing moral courage (Table 1).Table 1.PRISMA flow diagram for Web of Science data collection.
Overall trends in publications and citations
Figure 1 illustrates the publication trends in the domain of nursing moral courage. From the initial publication in 2002 through 2023, there was a consistent and discernible upward trajectory in the number of articles, indicative of an overarching growth trend. Regarding the average annual publication rate, the trend delineates two distinct stages: (1) from 2002 to 2019, characterized as a gestation period, during which the number of publications remained in the single digits; and (2) since 2020, witnessing a rapid proliferation in nursing moral courage research.Figure 1.Total publications from 2002 to 2023.
Country distribution
About 89.5% (94/105) of the publications were from the top 10 productive countries or regions shown in Table 2. The United States ranked first with 28 published articles, accounting for 26.7% of all 105 publications and far exceeding the numbers of other countries. Finland was second (12/105, 11.4%), followed by China (11/105, 10.5%).Table 2.Top 10 publication countries/regions (N = 105).
Journal distribution
Table 3 displays the top 10 journals based on publication count, along with their respective total citation frequencies. As anticipated, Nursing Ethics ranked first with 31 publications, constituting 29.5% of the total 105 articles, and boasted the highest citation frequency at 565 citations. This outcome aligns with expectations, given the longstanding emphasis within nursing ethics on nurturing and fostering moral courage among nurses. Notably, Nursing Ethics serves as a repository of exemplars and narratives illustrating nurses’ adherence to ethical principles and demonstration of moral courage. Consequently, it not only offers insights into the experiences of nurses but also serves as a source of inspiration and reference for readers.Table 3.Top 10 most productive journals. (N = 105).
Table 3 reveals a discrepancy between the ranking of journals based on the number of articles published and their corresponding citation counts. Certain journals exhibit relatively high citation counts despite their comparatively modest publication output, suggestive of the potential variance in the quality of publications across these journals.
Co-occurrence of keywords
Keywords can serve as indirect indicators of trends and shifts in research topics, facilitating a comprehensive understanding of their evolution. Employing VOSviewer, we constructed a keyword co-occurrence network (depicted in Figure 2). Furthermore, Table 4 presents the top 10 keywords based on their occurrence frequency. Notably, “moral courage” emerged as the most frequently occurring keyword, appearing 44 times, with a total link strength of 77. Additionally, keywords such as “nurses,” “ethics,” “moral distress,” and “nursing” are prominently featured, ranking highly in both occurrence frequency and connection strength.Figure 2.Keyword co-occurrence network.Table 4.Top 14 most frequently occurring keywords of nursing moral courage.
Keyword timeline graph
Keyword co-occurrence analysis unveils the evolution of research topics within a designated field over a specified time period. Through the generation of a timeline clustering graph predicated on clustered keywords, it delineates the historical progression and temporal duration of distinct keyword developments within each cluster. Utilizing the timeline view module within CiteSpace software, we produced a timeline map illustrating the research keywords pertaining to nursing moral courage, as depicted in Figure 3.Figure 3.Keyword timeline graph.
Keywords with the strongest citation bursts
Keywords exhibiting the most pronounced citation bursts can delineate periodic fluctuations in the prevalence of specific terms, thus facilitating prognostication of developmental trends and emerging research frontiers within the field. Leveraging the burst detection functionality of CiteSpace software, a statistical graph depicting keyword bursts within the domain of nursing moral courage was generated. In this graph, red indicates keywords experiencing bursts in a given year, while blue signifies non-burst keywords. Additionally, “Begin” and “End” denote the commencement and conclusion of each burst period, respectively, while “Strength” quantifies the intensity of the keyword burst, with higher values denoting greater influence (Figure 4).Figure 4.Keywords with the strongest citation bursts.
Author distribution
Table 5 presents the top 10 most productive authors. A total of 10 articles were published by Leino-Kilpi, who ranks first in terms of citations.Table 5.Top 10 most productive authors.
We also analyzed co-authorships using VOSviewer. In Figure 5, color represents cluster, node size represents publications, and link thickness represents collaboration strength.Figure 5.Co-authorship network based on publications.
The number of articles published by an author does not reflect the quality or popularity of their work. We thus further analyzed the co-authorship network based on citations (Figure 6).Figure 6.Co-authorship network of authors based on citations.
To better reflect the impact and contributions of the authors’ research, we conducted a co-citation analysis of the cited references in 105 articles (Figure 7).Figure 7.Co-citation network.
Articles with high citation numbers
Based on the keyword co-occurrence and author co-operation analysis, we further explored the cited articles. Table 6 reports the top 10 articles according to number of citations.Table 6.Top 10 articles according to number of citations.
Discussion
The primary objective of this research was to examine the scholarly output in the domain of moral courage in nursing through a mixed-method approach incorporating bibliometric analysis, mapping techniques, and thematic analysis. This methodology was employed to contextualize our research within a wider interdisciplinary framework that integrates insights from nursing ethics, psychology, and social science, thus providing a comprehensive perspective on the subject matter. In our research, we employed bibliometric analysis using VOSviewer and CiteSpace, which are robust tools for visualizing and analyzing patterns in scientific literature. The strengths of these tools lie in their ability to provide quantitative, objective data that help identify trends, key authors, institutions, and thematic shifts within the domain of nursing moral courage. VOSviewer, in particular, is renowned for its superior visualization capabilities, enabling detailed network and cluster analyses that are crucial for understanding the interconnections within the data. CiteSpace offers excellent support for literature timeline analyses, helping to highlight the evolution of research topics over time.
Our literature bibliometric analysis identified two distinct phases in the field. The initial phase, spanning from 2002 to 2019, was characterized by limited research activity, typically yielding single-digit annual publications. However, a significant surge in research was noted from 2020 onwards, coinciding with the global outbreak of COVID-19. This period has been marked by a robust increase in publication volume, suggesting a watershed moment in the field.
In numerous nations, nurses find themselves operating amidst the challenges posed by the ongoing pandemic, contending with insufficient resources and personal protective equipment, a surge in patient numbers, staffing deficits, inadequately prepared healthcare systems, and disruptions in the supply chain. This situation exacts a toll on the physical and emotional well-being of nurses and other healthcare and emergency personnel, inducing moral distress stemming from conflicts between professional values. They confront daunting and intricate ethical dilemmas in their daily practice, characterized by moral quandaries, heightened patient acuity, increased mortality rates, and prolonged work shifts. The exigencies of frontline pandemic response demand nurses to exhibit robust moral courage.3 The challenges created by COVID-19 can shape the students’ professional identity, making nursing students think about how to become excellent nurses.25 Nevertheless, it is undeniable that factors brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic will seriously affect their moral courage.26 Therefore, it may be under the influence of COVID-19 that research on nursing moral courage has shown explosive growth, highlighting the importance of moral courage in nursing.
While the COVID-19 pandemic undeniably played a pivotal role in this surge—necessitating robust moral courage among nurses who faced unprecedented challenges such as resource shortages, patient surges, and heightened ethical dilemmas—it is important to acknowledge that moral courage in nursing has also been influenced by other factors. Prior to the pandemic, topics such as authentic leadership,27 moral distress,28 and moral sensitivity20 were already prominent themes in moral courage research. These areas have contributed to a rich foundation of knowledge that has been critical in framing the current understanding of moral courage in the face of a pandemic. These factors have been fundamental in preparing nurses to handle the complex ethical situations that have become more frequent during the pandemic. Additionally, our analysis of the top 10 ranked keywords over the years highlights how concepts like “ethical decision-making,” “resilience,” and “professional integrity” have remained central to discussions on moral courage, alongside the recent focus on COVID-19. In summary, while the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted and intensified the need for moral courage in nursing, it is one of several critical factors that have shaped research in this field. Recognizing the broader spectrum of influences enriches our understanding and ensures a comprehensive exploration of moral courage in nursing.
According to research findings, the top 10 countries and regions in terms of published papers are mostly Western countries, except for China and Iran. However, this does not directly imply a lack of moral courage among nurses in Eastern countries and regions. In Confucianism, a prominent philosophical tradition in China, moral courage is construed as a form of courage associated with righteousness, ethics, and rational understanding, as evidenced by mentions in the writings of Confucius and Mencius. However, they did not specifically address what moral courage entails for nurses. This parallels the stance of Western philosophical scholars, as the term “moral courage” did not emerge in English until the 19th century, distinguishing it from other forms of courage such as physical courage.29 Presently, Western scholars have conducted research on the concept of moral courage in nursing, a topic relatively scarce in Eastern countries. Current research has not juxtaposed the conceptual and substantive disparities concerning nursing moral courage between Eastern and Western countries. Hence, this remains an area necessitating further investigation in the future.
It is also important to consider the relative contribution of each country in the context of their overall research output. For instance, while the United States produced the highest number of articles, its extensive research infrastructure and larger population naturally contribute to higher publication numbers across various topics, including nursing moral courage. Conversely, Finland, despite being smaller and having fewer research institutions, shows a remarkably high relational share in this specific area, underscoring its significant impact and specialization in nursing moral courage research. This highlights the importance of evaluating the relative impact of smaller countries, which can have a substantial influence despite producing fewer publications overall.
From the perspective of the most prolific journals, “Nursing Ethics” remains in the lead, having published a total of 31 scholarly articles, constituting 29.5% of the entire corpus. Additionally, half of the most frequently cited top 10 references are from “Nursing Ethics.” This journal, dedicated to nursing ethics, concentrates the dissemination of research findings on nursing moral courage; hence, its prominent position in this field is unsurprising. Furthermore, other journals such as BMC Nursing have also featured content related to moral courage, indicating that researchers seek opportunities not only to publish articles on moral courage in journals specifically focused on nursing ethics but also to integrate such content into more broadly accessible journals, such as those in psychology or education.
From the analysis of the top 10 most frequently occurring keywords related to nursing moral courage, it is evident that besides moral courage itself, there is a prevalence of keywords associated with moral dilemmas, ethics, and virtues. Nursing, as a moral practice, necessitates the courage to uphold ethical standards, take a firm stance on what is right, and live according to one’s moral values.2 Moral courage is not only a highly esteemed element in human morality but also a recognized virtue in contemporary nursing.30 Nurses encounter moral dilemmas in their daily practice, which should be resolved in the best interest of the patients, aligning with the moral aims of nursing.31 Thus, moral courage is introduced as an empowering mechanism for addressing these issues.
From the collaborative outcomes of the authors, it is disappointing. Since the era of Florence Nightingale in nursing literature, there has been a longstanding discourse on moral courage,2 which should be a fundamental characteristic of excellent nurses. However, to date, it has not received the same level of attention as discussions on moral dilemmas32 nor has it formed a realm of extensive scholarly collaboration. Perhaps this also represents a future research trend, namely, strengthening collaboration across multiple global regions.
Through comprehensive analysis combining keyword clustering, keyword timelines, authors, and countries, future research trends in nursing moral courage may manifest in several aspects. Firstly, there is a global perspective. Given the interplay of global nursing practices, researchers may adopt a global perspective to compare the manifestations of nursing moral courage and its influencing factors across different countries and regions, thereby fostering a global dialogue on nursing ethics. Secondly, interdisciplinary research is likely to emerge. Considering that moral courage encompasses multiple fields such as ethics, psychology, and sociology, future studies may employ interdisciplinary research methods and collaborate with philosophers, psychologists, sociologists, and others to gain a more comprehensive understanding of nursing moral courage. Lastly, education may become a focal point. As nursing education evolves, integrating content on moral courage into nursing curricula and cultivating moral courage in nursing students will become important research directions. This may include incorporating elements such as moral decision-making and discussions on ethical dilemmas into the curriculum. Naturally, as these studies progress, the definition and connotations of nursing moral courage will deepen, and research tools will become more diversified.
Limitations
This study has three main limitations. Firstly, in terms of data selection, the WoS Core Collection was chosen, while other databases such as Scopus were not included. Secondly, this research primarily focuses on journals, paying less attention to other modes of scientific knowledge dissemination (such as books, working papers, and reports). Lastly, we only analyzed English publications, potentially introducing language bias. Additionally, bibliometric analysis, while powerful for mapping out the landscape of a research domain, may not capture the full depth of individual studies’ contributions or the nuances of qualitative research. It relies heavily on the availability and accuracy of citation data, which can be influenced by factors such as publication bias and the varying impact factors of journals. This method also does not address the quality of the content itself, focusing instead on quantitative metrics. Future research could compare articles published in different languages or countries.
Conclusion
From a methodological perspective, it can be asserted that the innovative application of bibliometric analysis and mapping constitutes valuable tools for the analysis of literature production in the field of nursing moral courage. This study utilizes VOSviewer and CiteSpace visualization analysis tools to systematically review and summarize research on nursing moral courage. We roughly delineate it into two phases, and bibliometric analysis suggests that there is still room for further exploration of nursing moral courage in terms of content and geography. However, this does not diminish its significance in addressing ethical dilemmas encountered in nursing practice. It is noteworthy that this paper also forecasts future research trends in nursing moral courage, indicating that researchers may strengthen research on nursing moral courage by adopting a global perspective, engaging in interdisciplinary studies, and focusing on nursing education. The results proposed in this paper can serve as a starting point for comprehensive or systematic literature reviews and seek more detailed data, information, and knowledge in the field of nursing moral courage. It can enable outsiders to quickly understand research on nursing moral courage, whether for in-depth exploration or simply to facilitate more effective collaboration with nursing ethics experts.

Body
SAS Institute, a business analytics software and services provider, issued the following news release:
* * *
PZU models AI governance for the insurance industry
Insurer works with SAS AI Governance Advisory to protect customers and drive AI ethics
In a recent survey about the growing use of generative AI in insurance by data and AI leader SAS, 57% of insurance sector respondents described their organizations' AI governance and monitoring frameworks as "in development." More than a quarter (27%) said their frameworks were "ad hoc or informal," and about 1 in 10 (11%) reported their AI governance was "nonexistent."
Against this backdrop, Powszechny Zaklad Ubezpieczen S.A., better known as PZU, one of the largest financial institutions in central Europe, has worked with the SAS AI Governance Advisory to develop and implement a comprehensive AI governance framework. This framework protects customers, advances regulatory compliance and keeps the insurer on the leading edge of responsible innovation.
"While we are in an era of out-of-the-box AI solutions, data ethics is anything but one-size-fits-all," said Reggie Townsend, Vice President of Data Ethics at SAS. "AI governance, customized to ensure safe deployment, is the future of industry AI.
"Regulatory compliance is just a starting point. Robust oversight guided by an organization's data maturity, unique culture and growth goals maximizes AI's value while limiting risk."
Inspiring insurance evolution
PZU, a 200-year-old institution, has leveraged the potential of data across hundreds of integrated systems for nearly three decades. Several hundred AI and machine learning (ML) models drive essential business functions each day.
A pioneer in comprehensive data management, quality assurance and ethical use, PZU invested years ago in developing data governance practices, including establishing a team to set policies and coordinate data governance and quality processes.
As a surge of fresh regulation followed the post-ChatGPT AI boom, PZU's leadership quickly realized that modernizing its AI supervision and governance mechanism was a commitment not only to meeting compliance mandates but also to preparing for the future challenges of technology development.
PZU selected the SAS AI Governance Advisory, a new service for SAS customers, as one of the collaborators who would pilot the project. SAS' continued investment in responsible innovation, centered around its industry-leading Data Ethics Practice, determined the choice.
PZU has long trusted SAS solutions to pilot core business functions like sales and customer relationship management, fraud detection, claims automation, customer service and risk management. Establishing a new AI governance framework together was a logical next step.
Tailored to insure tomorrow
The SAS AI Governance Advisory consulted with PZU in four stages to create custom best practices for the insurer:
1. Oversight: Advising on PZU's innovation goals and helping them set policies for AI governance strategy and enforcement.
2. Compliance: Exploring PZU's compliance needs and discussing readiness for regulatory standards.
3. Operations: Reccommending operational procedures for AI and data management taking into account PZU's goals, regulatory requirements and the culture they aim to create.
4. Culture: Collaborating to foster positive social norms within the insurer's culture that would empower employees to adhere to trustworthy AI practices.
In the process, PZU and SAS experts defined policies for the entire lifecycle of all the insurer's AI/ML models to ensure adequate data quality, optimal resource use and continuous monitoring.

"PZU intends to meet this challenge by harnessing the potential of data and AI to address key industry issues, the effects of climate change among them.

The future of trustworthy innovation in insurance

Byline: Karcy Noonan
Body
April 10th, 2025 ( International Business Times India  - Delivered by  Newstex )
Business Intelligence(BI) is a cornerstone of modern decision-making, leveraging vast data to uncover insights and drive strategy. However, as BI systems evolve, ethical concerns around privacy, transparency, and fairness become increasingly pressing. Mallikarjun Bussa, a prominent expert in data ethics, explores these challenges in his recent work, highlighting innovative solutions that organizations are adopting to navigate this complex landscape.
Bridging the Privacy Paradox with Cutting-Edge Techniques
The fundamental challenge in BI ethics is the "privacy paradox" the tension between extracting valuable insights and protecting individual privacy. Organizations are pioneering solutions like differential privacy, which mathematically obscures individual identities while maintaining analytical accuracy. Additionally, federated learning allows AI models to train across multiple decentralized datasets without data ever leaving its original location, significantly reducing privacy risks.
Another emerging approach is homomorphic encryption, enabling data analysis while keeping it encrypted. This technology is gaining traction in sectors like finance, where detecting fraud patterns without exposing sensitive financial information is critical. These innovations demonstrate that businesses do not have to choose between privacy and insight; they can achieve both with the right safeguards.
Combating Algorithmic Bias for Fairer Outcomes
BI-driven decisions impact hiring, lending, healthcare, and more, making algorithmic fairness crucial. Unchecked biases in training data can lead to discriminatory outcomes, but organizations are now implementing bias detection and mitigation frameworks to ensure fairness.
Pre-processing methods adjust data before training models, in-processing techniques constrain AI learning to prevent bias, and post-processing strategies correct biased outputs. By combining these methods, companies significantly reduce bias while maintaining accuracy. Moreover, diverse data science teams and continuous auditing of BI systems contribute to developing fairer, more ethical AI models.
Regular audits ensure ongoing compliance with ethical standards. Transparent documentation of bias mitigation strategies builds stakeholder trust and enables effective governance of AI deployment across enterprise environments.
Transparency as a Trust-Building Tool
Stakeholders increasingly demand visibility into how their data is used. Many businesses are responding by enhancing transparency through explainable AI (XAI) technologies such as Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) and Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations (LIME). These methods provide human-understandable justifications for AI decisions, fostering trust and improving regulatory compliance.
In addition to XAI, leading companies are introducing user-friendly data dashboards, allowing customers to see what data is collected and how it informs recommendations. Research shows that organizations prioritizing transparency experience higher customer retention and reduced legal risks, making it a win-win strategy.
Implementing Robust Ethical Safeguards
Beyond privacy and transparency, organizations are embedding ethics directly into BI design. Data minimization strategies ensure that only necessary information is collected, reducing privacy risks. Context-aware access controls prevent unauthorized data use by factoring in user roles, locations, and query patterns.
Many businesses are also adopting "ethics-by-design" approaches, where ethical impact assessments are conducted during system development rather than as a reactive measure. Regular audits further enhance accountability, identifying and mitigating potential ethical concerns before they escalate.
Cross-functional ethical review boards now provide governance throughout the AI lifecycle. Industry collaborations are establishing shared ethical standards, while regulatory frameworks increasingly mandate fairness assessments.
In conclusion,As BI technologies advance, ethical considerations will become even more integral to business strategy. The rise of global data protection regulations is driving standardization, making compliance frameworks more consistent across industries. Meanwhile, AI governance models are evolving to ensure that ethical safeguards keep pace with technological progress.Investing in ethical BI practices is not just about avoiding regulatory penalties it is a competitive advantage. Organizations with robust data ethics programs report stronger customer loyalty, reduced operational risks, and increased market valuation. As Mallikarjun Bussaemphasizes, the future belongs to businesses that can balance analytical power with responsible data stewardship.

2025 MAY 02 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- New research on Robotics is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Tokushima, Japan, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "This review discusses the introduction of healthcare robots, such as those that provide transfer, toileting, bathing, and communication assistance, in Japanese facilities for older adults and considers these issues from the perspective of nursing ethics. Although healthcare robots can support older adults and their caregivers, they may cause ethical dilemmas when introduced in assisted living facilities." 
 The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Tokushima Graduate School, "Nurses should make ethical decisions by considering different types of information to determine the best care for older adults ; they can resolve ethical dilemmas by referring to the 6 principles of nursing ethics. As healthcare robots are increasingly used in the care of older adults, nurses should protect patients' rights and ensure patient safety." 
 According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Further, engineers and medical professionals must discuss and share issues related to the use of healthcare robots to build improved robotic technology for older adults. J. Med. Invest. 72 : 8-13, February,." 
 This research has been peer-reviewed. 
 For more information on this research see: Current State of Healthcare Robots for Older Adults in Care Facilities in Japan and the Related Ethical Issues for Nurses. The Journal of Medical Investigation, 2025;72:8-13. 
 Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Yuko Yasuhara, Dept. of Nursing Art and Science, Institute of Health Biosciences, University of Tokushima Graduate School, Tokushima, Japan. 
 Keywords for this news article include: Tokushima, Japan, Asia, Emerging Technologies, Health and Medicine, Machine Learning, Nano-robot, Nursing Ethics, Robotics. 
 Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

Byline: Ali Haddad
Ann Gallagher
Body
The 20th International Pan Arab Critical Care Medicine Society (IPACCMS) Conference and the 1st Pan Arab Conference of the World Federation of Intensive and Critical Care societies, held in Kuwait, was a landmark event that brought together healthcare professionals, researchers, and thought leaders from across the globe. Organized by the Kuwait Anaesthesia and Critical Care Society, the conference attracted 1800 participants, featured 110 speakers, including 40 local experts, and delivered over 130 lectures across three parallel tracks. Additionally, 500 attendees participated in pre-conference workshops, which covered 14 specialized topics.
The conference fostered a vibrant exchange of knowledge and expertise. While the scientific programme covered a wide range of clinical topics, including sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiogenic shock, and the transformative role of artificial intelligence (AI) in critical care, the ethical dimensions of healthcare were a recurring theme, both explicitly and implicitly. This Editorial captures reflection on the conference from a nursing ethics perspective, highlighting key ethical issues and their implications for critical care nursing practice, education, research, and leadership.
The pre-conference workshops from 30th to 31st January 2025 and 3-day main programme from 1st to 3rd February 2025 were rich with insights regarding the latest advances in critical care and medicine. Whereas there was only one explicit session on Day 3 of the main conference on ‘Ethical Challenges in Critical Care’, ethical issues and concepts were implicit in most sessions. At the beginning of each session, for example, speakers declared conflicts of interest; they weighed benefits and harms in relation to critical care treatment and research; they shared how they prioritized patient and family perspectives; and they highlighted the importance of ethical leadership, role modelling, and good teaching.
The pre-conference critical care nursing workshop, entitled ‘Advancing Excellence in Critical Care Nursing: Empowering Minds, Leadership, and Innovation,’ provided a platform for critical discussions on ethical challenges faced by nurses in Kuwait and beyond. The workshop explored the unique role of nurses as advocates, educators, and caregivers, while also addressing ethical dilemmas inherent in their practice. Key themes included multicultural working in healthcare; nurse advocacy; communication and respect; end-of-life care; ethics education and support; and culturally appropriate ethical frameworks.
Multicultural working in healthcare
Nurses often work in diverse teams and care for patients from varied cultural backgrounds. This diversity, while enriching, can also lead to ethical tensions, particularly when cultural beliefs conflict with medical recommendations or when communication barriers arise. The workshop emphasized the need for cultural competence and sensitivity in navigating these challenges. As Leininger1 notes in her seminal work on transcultural nursing, understanding and respecting cultural differences is essential for providing ethically sound and patient-centred care.
Nurse advocacy
Nurses frequently find themselves advocating for patients when families or other stakeholders may not appear to prioritize the patient’s best interests. This role requires moral courage, resilience, and a commitment to patient autonomy and dignity. According to Grace and Uveges,2 advocacy is a core ethical obligation of nursing, rooted in the profession’s commitment to safeguarding patient rights and well-being.
Communication and respect
Effective communication is a cornerstone of ethical care, yet disrespectful or dismissive behaviour in healthcare settings remains a challenge. Nurses must often mediate conflicts and ensure that all voices are heard, particularly in high-stakes critical care environments. Research by Brooks et al.3 highlights the importance of patient-centred communication in fostering trust and ensuring ethical care delivery.
End-of-life care
Ethical dilemmas surrounding end-of-life care were a recurring theme, especially in contexts where legal or cultural norms discourage the discontinuation of treatment. Nurses play a crucial role in balancing respect for cultural values with the principles of beneficence and non-maleficence. As highlighted in a study by Gallagher et al.,4 nurses often experience moral distress when navigating end-of-life decisions, underscoring the need for ethical frameworks that support both patients and caregivers.
Ethics education and support
The workshop highlighted the need for robust ethics education and support systems to help nurses navigate moral distress and ethical unpreparedness. This includes fostering moral resilience, providing access to ethics consultations, and creating spaces for reflective practice. Rushton5 emphasizes the importance of moral resilience in enabling nurses to sustain their ethical commitment in the face of adversity.
Culturally appropriate ethical frameworks
Nurses are uniquely positioned to develop ethical frameworks that are culturally sensitive and context-specific. Such frameworks can empower nurses to deliver care that is both ethically sound and culturally respectful. As argued by Johnstone and Kanitsaki,6 culturally responsive ethics is essential for addressing the diverse needs of patients and families in a globalized healthcare environment.
Conclusions
In addition to these themes, the workshop also touched on the importance of moral resilience, interprofessional ethics, and the strengthening of nurses’ professional identity. Concepts such as non-abandonment and trustworthiness were emphasized as central to the ethics of care in critical care nursing. These principles align with the work of Tronto,7 who argues that care ethics – rooted in relationality, responsibility, and attentiveness – provides a robust foundation for ethical nursing practice.
The conference was a powerful reminder of the ethical complexities inherent in critical care nursing. It highlighted the need for ongoing dialogue, education, and support to equip nurses with the tools they need to navigate these challenges. As the healthcare landscape continues to evolve, particularly with the integration of advanced technologies like AI, the ethical dimensions of nursing practice will only grow in importance. The 20th IPACCMS served as a call to action for nurses, educators, and leaders to prioritize ethics in their practice and to continue advocating for patient-centred, culturally sensitive, and ethically grounded care.
In conclusion, the conference was not only a celebration of scientific and clinical advances but also a profound exploration of the ethical heart of critical care nursing. It reminded us that while technology and research are essential, it is the ethical commitment of nurses that truly sustains the humanity of healthcare. As we reflect on the insights gained, let us carry forward the lessons learned and continue to strive for excellence in both the science and the ethics of critical care nursing.
Bibliography
REFERENCES
1 Leininger M, . Culture care theory: a major contribution to advance transcultural nursing knowledge and practices. J Transcult Nurs 2002; 13(3): 189–192.
2 Grace PJ, Uveges MK, . Nursing ethics and professional responsibility in advanced practice. Burlington, MA: Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2022.
3 Brooks LA, Bloomer MJ, Manias E, . Culturally sensitive communication at the end-of-life in the intensive care unit: a systematic review. Aust Crit Care 2019; 32(6): 516–523.
4 Gallagher A, Bousso RS, McCarthy J, , et al. Negotiated reorienting: a grounded theory of nurses’ end-of-life decision-making in the intensive care unit. Int J Nurs Stud 2015; 52(4): 794–803.
5 Rushton CH, . Moral resilience: transforming moral suffering in healthcare. New York, NY: Oxford University Press, 2024.
6 Johnstone MJ, Kanitsaki O, . Ethics and advance care planning in a culturally diverse society. J Transcult Nurs 2009; 20(4): 405–416.
7 Tronto JC, . Creating caring institutions: politics, plurality, and purpose. Ethics Soc Welfare 2010; 4(2): 158–171.

Body
[Category: BizLaw/Legal] -- Taft, a law firm, issued the following news:
* * *
Sheehan to Serve as Panelist at 2025 TLA Annual Conference
Taft attorney Cari Sheehan will serve as a panelist at the 2025 Transportation Lawyers Association (TLA) Annual Conference. The conference will provide insightful discussion on artificial intelligence and cybersecurity risks in legal practice, ethical obligations in using emerging technologies, and key rules of professional conduct that attorneys must follow. The conference will be held April 30 - May 3 and Sheehan will present on Friday, May 2.
With over 15 years of legal experience in civil litigation, conflicts of interest, and professional responsibility, Sheehan serves as the firm's Assistant General Counsel. In this role, she advises firm attorneys with respect to ethics compliance, risk prevention, and conflicts of interest. In addition, she assists in the review and negotiation of outside counsel guidelines, conflict waivers and engagement letters, and other items with ethical implications. In addition, she assists in providing ethical training and education within the firm to its attorneys and staff. Sheehan is an Adjunct Professor at the IU Robert H. McKinney School where she teaches Professional Responsibility. She is also a former Assistant Clinical Professor of Business Law and Ethics at the Kelley School of Business. She is passionate about promoting ethical awareness, integrity, and professionalism in the legal and business fields and contributing to the advancement of knowledge and practice in these domains.
***
Original text here: https://www.taftlaw.com/news-events/news/sheehan-to-serve-as-panelist-at-2025-tla-annual-conference/

Body
Chris Kissack, business development manager at trust and corporate services provider Acclaim Limited, has become the first individual in the island to earn the Open Data Institute's (ODI) Data Ethics Professional certification. 
This certification from the Open Data Institute (ODI) is globally recognised and equips professionals to lead on ethical, responsible use of data and artificial intelligence. 
A spokesperson for the Douglas firm said about the qualification: 'It marks a meaningful step for the island as conversations around AI shift from adoption to accountability. 
'It also reflects Acclaim's broader focus on equipping its team and the wider business community with the tools needed to navigate emerging technologies responsibly.'
Mr Kissack added: 'I am incredibly proud to have qualified as a certified data ethics professional with the Open Data Institute, not just because it was a lot of study and hard work, but because it will enhance our services to our clients. 
'How businesses and professionals obtain, use, and share data has never been more important, so understanding and being able to utilise different frameworks and methodologies is incredibly valuable. 
'Being the first in the island to obtain this accreditation is a career highlight for me, something I could not have achieved without the incredible encouragement and support from my colleagues at Acclaim, but I hope it will not be long before other data professionals on the island follow suit, bolstering the Isle of Man's reputation for a centre of excellence for data and AI.'
Stuart Coleman, director of learning and consultancy at the London-based Open Data Institute, said: 'Chris joins hundreds of Data Ethics Professionals all around the world. 
'Data ethics and responsible AI are pressing concerns for many organisations across a wide range of sectors. 
'The Data Ethics Professional certification gives people the tools and skills they need to build trust and transparency, ensuring that their organisations are well placed to maximise the benefits of data and AI while minimising the risks. 
'The Open Data Institute is very pleased that Chris has joined many other data leaders from around the world.'
Chris's achievement comes as the Isle of Man launched its government-led AI initiative (Activate AI) last year, designed to raise awareness, education, and adoption of AI across the island. 
Led by Digital Isle of Man, the programme brings together public and private partners to deliver practical, grounded guidance on emerging technologies.
As a training partner, Acclaim Limited has delivered workshops and shared insights to help businesses move from theory to action, ensuring that ethics and responsibility remain at the heart of innovation.
Founded in 2006, Acclaim Limited is a licensed trust and corporate services provider based in Hill Street.

2025 APR 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on artificial intelligence. According to news reporting out of Brescia, Italy, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Machine Learning (ML) has historically been associated with Artificial Intelligence (AI) but has developed into an independent discipline." 
 Funders for this research include European Union-next Generation Eu, Mission 4, Component 2, Under Grant Agreement. 
 Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Catholic University of the Sacred Heart: "This paper argues for the ontological independence of ML, driven by its unique methodologies, applications, and ethical considerations. A bibliometric analysis reveals that ML research output (494,572 publications from 2017-2023) surpasses AI (283,762 publications) by 74%, reflecting its rapid growth and specialization. Unlike AI's pursuit of general intelligence and symbolic reasoning, ML focuses on data-driven performance optimization, with impactful applications in computer vision, natural language processing (NLP), and autonomous systems. The study highlights ethical challenges-such as addressing algorithmic bias (50 occurrences), fairness (2,778 publications), and environmental sustainability (283 related works)-which emphasize the need for dedicated ethical frameworks tailored to ML. These findings propose a conceptual and practical separation between ML and AI to enable targeted research, interdisciplinary collaboration, and solutions to challenges like explainability, transparency, and sustainability." 
 According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The paper underscores the importance of recognizing ML's independence in advancing both fields." 
 For more information on this research see: Breaking Away From AI: The Ontological and Ethical Evolution of Machine Learning. IEEE Access, 2025,13():55627-55647. (IEEE Access - http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/servlet/opac?punumber=6287639). The publisher for IEEE Access is IEEE. 
 A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2025.3553032. 
 Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Enrico Barbierato, Faculty of Mathematical, Physical and Natural Sciences, Catholic University of the Sacred Heart, Brescia, Italy. Additional authors for this research include Alice Gatti, Alessandro Incremona, Andrea Pozzi, Daniele Toti. 
 Keywords for this news article include: Catholic University of the Sacred Heart, Brescia, Italy, Europe, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning. 
 Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC
